notes.content: Substitute: What can be replaced? These might be materials, people, or rules that can be replaced to change the function.

Combine: What features, uses or components can be combined? Are there features of products that could be synthesized to provide a better, more holistic product? If looking at a project rather than a product, are there different team members that can combine their work?

Adapt: What can be slightly tweaked to improve the product or process? Could a solution to one issue be adapted to help solve a different issue? In what ways does the product/process need to change to adapt itself to changing lifestyles?

Modify (or sometimes, minify/magnify): How can the process be changed in a way that changes the outcomes? What can you magnify to emphasize a particular part of the process, or what can you minify to improve the overall efficiency? Can you modify the shape, color, or size?

Put to another use: What benefits might be gained by using the process/product in a different field? Is there another industry in which the product can succeed? How can this product be used in a way that differs from its initial intent?
Eliminate: Sometimes, the best way to make a product better is to eliminate some of the unnecessary components. What can be removed or simplified? Is there a way to better streamline the product?
Reverse: Would changing the sequence of effects produce a different outcome? What can be rearranged, flipped, or swapped?

1. Segmentation

  1. Divide an object into independent parts.
  2. Make an object sectional (for easy assembly or disassembly).
  3. Increase the degree of an object’s segmentation.

2. Extraction (Extracting, Retrieving, Removing)

  1. Extract the “disturbing” part or property from an object.
  2. Extract only the necessary part or property from an object.

3. Local Quality

  1. Transition from homogeneous to heterogeneous structure of an object or outside environment (action).
  2. Different parts of an object should carry out different functions.
  3. Each part of an object should be placed under conditions that are most favorable for its operation.

4. Asymmetry

  1. Replace symmetrical forms with asymmetrical forms.
  2. If an object is already asymmetrical, increase its degree of asymmetry.

5. Consolidation

  1. Consolidate in space homogeneous objects, or objects destined for contiguous operations.
  2. Consolidate in time homogeneous or contiguous operations.

6. Universality

  1. An object can perform several different functions; therefore, other elements can be removed.

7. Nesting (Matrioshka)

  1. One object is placed inside another. That object is placed inside a third one and so on...
  2. An object passes through a cavity in another object.

8. Counterweight

  1. Compensate for the weight of an object by combining it with another object that provides a lifting force.
  2. Compensate for the weight of an object with aerodynamic or hydrodynamic forces influenced by the outside environment.

9. Prior Counteraction

  1. Preload countertension to an object to compensate excessive and undesirable stress.

10. Prior Action

  1. Perform required changes to an object completely or partially in advance.
  2. Place objects in advance so that they can go into action immediately from the most convenient location.

11. Cushon in Advance

  1. Compensate for the relatively low reliability of an object with emergency measures prepared in advance.

12. Equipotentiality

  1. Change the condition of the work in such a way that it will not require lifting or lowering an object.

13. Do It in Reverse

  1. Instead of the direct action dictated by a problem, implement an opposite action (i.e., cooling instead of heating).
  2. Make the movable part of an object, or outside environment, stationary — and stationary part moveable.
  3. Turn an object upside-down.

14. Spheroidality

  1. Replace linear parts with curved parts, flat surfaces with spherical surfaces, and cube shapes with ball shapes.
  2. Use rollers, balls, spirals.
  3. Replace linear motion with rotational motion; utilize centrifugal force.

15. Dynamicity

  1. Characteristics of an object or outside environment, must be altered to provide optimal performance at each stage of an operation.
  2. If an object is immobile, make it mobile. Make it interchangeable.
  3. Divide an object into elements capable of changing their position relative to each other.

16. Partial or Excessive Action

  1. If it is difficult to obtain 100% of a desired effect, achieve more or less of the desired effect.

17. Transition Into a New Dimension

  1. Transition one-dimensional movement, or placement, of objects into two-dimensional; two-dimensional to three-dimensional, etc.
  2. Utilize multi-level composition of objects.
  3. Incline an object, or place it on its side.
  4. Utilize the opposite side of a given surface.
  5. Project optical lines onto neighboring areas, or onto the reverse side, of an object.

18. Mechanical Vibration

  1. Utilize oscillation.
  2. If oscillation exists, increase its frequency to ultrasonic.
  3. Use the frequency of resonance.
  4. Replace mechanical vibrations with piezovibrations.
  5. Use ultrasonic vibrations in conjunction with an electromagnetic field.

19. Periodic Action

  1. Replace a continuous action with a periodic one (impulse).
  2. If the action is already periodic, change its frequency.
  3. Use pauses between impulses to provide additional action.

20. Continuity of Useful Action

  1. Carry out an action without a break. All parts of the object should constantly operate at full capacity.
  2. Remove idle and intermediate motion.
  3. Replace “back-and-forth” motion with a rotating one.

21. Rushing Through

  1. Perform harmful and hazardous operations at a very high speed.

22. Convert Harm Into Benefit

  1. Utilize harmful factors — especially environmental — to obtain a positive effect.
  2. Remove one harmful factor by combining it with another harmful factor.
  3. Increase the degree of harmful action to such an extent that it ceases to be harmful.

23. Feedback

  1. Introduce feedback.
  2. If feedback already exists, change it.

24. Mediator

  1. Use an intermediary object to transfer or carry out an action.
  2. Temporarily connect the original object to one that is easily removed.

25. Self-service

  1. An object must service itself and carry out supplementary and repair operations.
  2. Make use of waste material and energy.

26. Copying

  1. A simplified and inexpensive copy should be used in place of a fragile original or an object that is inconvenient to operate.
  2. If a visible optical copy is used, replace it with an infrared or ultraviolet copies.
  3. Replace an object (or system of objects) with their optical image. The image can then be reduced or enlarged.

27. Dispose

  1. Replace an expensive object with a cheap one, compromising other properties (i.e., longevity).

28. Replacement of Mechanical System

  1. Replace a mechanical system with an optical, acoustical, thermal or olfactory system.
  2. Use an electric, magnetic or electromagnetic field to interact with an object.
  3. Replace fields that are:
    1. Stationary with mobile
    2. Fixed with changing in time
    3. Random with structured
  4. Use fields in conjunction with ferromagnetic

29. Pneumatic or Hydraulic Constructions

  1. Replace solid parts of an object with a gas or liquid. These parts can now use air or water for inflation, or use pneumatic or hydrostatic cushions.

30. Flexible Membranes or Thin Films

  1. Replace customary constructions with flexible membranes or thin film.
  2. Isolate an object from its outside environment with flexible membranes or thin films.

31. Porous Material

  1. Make an object porous, or use supplementary porous elements (inserts, covers, etc.).
  2. If an object is already porous, fill pores in advance with some substance.

32. Changing the Color

  1. Change the color of an object or its environment.
  2. Change the degree of translucency of an object or its environment.
  3. Use color additives to observe an object, or process which is difficult to see.
  4. If such additives are already used, employ luminescent traces or trace atoms.

33. Homogeneity

  1. Objects interacting with the main object should be made out of the same material (or material with similar properties) as the main object.

34. Rejecting and Regenerating Parts

  1. After completing its function, or becoming useless, an element of an object is rejected (discarded, dissolved, evaporated, etc.) or modified during its work process.
  2. Used-up parts of an object should be restored during its work.

35. Transformation of Properties

  1. Change the physical state of the system.
  2. Change the concentration or density.
  3. Change the degree of flexibility.
  4. Change the temperature or volume.

36. Phase Transition

  1. Using the phenomena of phase change (i.e., a change in volume, the liberation or absorption of heat, etc.).

37. Thermal Expansion

  1. Use expansion or contraction of material by changing its temperature.
  2. Use various materials with different coefficients of thermal expansion.

38. Accelerated Oxidation

  1. Make transition from one level of oxidation to the next higher level:
    1. Ambient air to oxygenated
    2. Oxygenated to oxygen
    3. Oxygen to ionized oxygen
    4. Ionized oxygen to ozoned oxygen
    5. Ozoned oxygen to ozone
    6. Ozone to singlet oxygen

39. Inert Environment

  1. Replace a normal environment with an inert one.
  2. Introduce a neutral substance or additives into an object.
  3. Carry out the process in a vacuum.

40. Composite Materials

  1. Replace homogeneous materials with composite ones.

• If you want to compute in the future, you have to compute with the computing power of the future
    • We spent roughly two to three times a person’s salary each year just on technology for that person
    • We bought our way into the future because Moore’s Law says that if you’re interested in something 15 years from now, you can have that computing power now if you’re willing to pay through the nose
cite: The Future Doesn't Have to Be Incremental

notes.content:
• The iPad has a much more brain dead interface than the Mac
  • But if you think of the iPad as a gesture device, the gesture is inherently something that gives you not just naturalness, but efficiency.
    • What you really want… is to learn a bunch of gestures to make you fluent and efficient on the thing
    • [But] the iPad doesn’t have any particular way of teaching you those gestures.
    • So basically everything has evolved down to the few system gestures that are generic to the iPad.
  • This kind of dumb-downism has been incredibly successful for… making money.
  • It has not been good for personal computing.
cite: The Future Doesn't Have to Be Incremental

notes.content:
• The idea of the Wayne Gretzky Game is to put the puck way out there, like 30 years out.
  • So far out that whatever you think about out there need have no visible way of getting there.
  • It’s just something that would be cool to have and/or important to have.
  • You [then] want to bring it closer in and start thinking about what would this thing be 10 to 15 years out.
  • And you start thinking, hmm, I wonder if there’s something we could do there.
    • But a device like this has hardware and software of the future.
    • And we have to do that now, because it’s going to take decades to do fundamental hardware and software for a new kind of thing.
    • And you can get that by paying. You just pay whatever Moore’s Law is going to save you later on.
cite: The Future Doesn't Have to Be Incremental

notes.content:
• A book called “The Human Use of Human Beings”
  • Out of MIT in 1952, by Norbert Wiener
  • The idea of cybernetics as “the study of messages as a means of controlling machinery and society”
  • That is: “let us not look at the person, but let us look at the messages going around”
cite: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• A book called “The Human Use of Human Beings”
  • Out of MIT in 1952, by Norbert Wiener
  • Another idea: we have modified our environment so radically, that we must now modify ourselves in order to exist in this new environment.
  • Then: how can we take a person and simplify it down to a machine, or a system that we can understand well?
    • And then once we are starting to think of people that way, well we can improve machines.
    • We can add things to them and the machines get more capabilities. Maybe that is how we move forward as people.
cite: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• The connecting thread in “Whole Earth Catalog”… is this idea of access to tools
  • Our relationship with our tools is going to be how we move forward
  • This catalog starts with “We are as gods and we might as well get good at it. So far, remotely done power and glory – as government, big business, formal education, church – has succeeded to the point where the gross defects obscure actual gains. In response, personal power is developing.”
cite: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• So I had this idea for intentional communication, the idea of conversation flows:

  • Instead of just having a blank box you write into…

    • You first choose some intent. “My intent is to learn”, let us say.

    • And I will get prompted to, say, “what is your background?”

    • And the question is, “Why do I have to explicitly cast between Int and Float when doing math?”

    • And then I can submit the post.

  • [And then] instead of just having a “reply” button, maybe you can say, “OK, I can either ask for clarification, or I can give an answer”.

    • And so if I say I am going to give an answer, again we might have this structured way of replying.

    • Restate the question, answer it, and then, hey we value citations.

    • And they can post it.

  • So we saw someone wants to learn, you can clarify or answer. If they choose to answer, they can ask a clarifying question, or thank you.

  • The point here is just that “Yell angrily” is not one of the states in the discussion flow. It is unreachable.
cite: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• “Beyond Freedom and Dignity” by B. F. Skinner says: “If planned culture necessarily meant uniformity or regimentation, it might indeed work against further evolution… but if we are looking for variety, we should not fall back upon accident. Many accidental cultures have been marked by uniformity and regimentation.”
  • I think this is one of the clearest books that is recognizing that:
    • there are these people who understand choice architectures, and that
    • freedom does not help you escape from choice architectures.
    • Design of other choice architectures is a way to deal with that.
cite: The Hard Parts Of Open Source

notes.content:
• There are two kinds of tools: user-friendly tools, and physics-friendly tools

  • User-friendly tools:

    • Wrap a particular domain around the habits of your mind

    • Feel like alert servants, and never let you forget that you exist

    • If you grow good enough at wielding them, they allow you to forget that they exist

  • Physics-friendly tools:

    • Wrap your mind around a particular domain

    • Feel like "real tools", and never let you forget that they exist

    • If you grow good enough at wielding them, they allow you to forget that you exist

• Doing more complex things like building robots takes a higher minimum level of tooling complexity
    • We do not live in a very user-friendly universe, but we do live in a fairly physics-friendly one
    • So you need something like a minimum-viable toolchain to do a given thing
  • Simpler, more user-friendly tooling is
    • the result of improved domain understanding,
    • not increased concern for human comfort and convenience
  • Fundamentally reducing the complexity of tooling required to do a thing requires understanding the thing itself better
    • Premature user-friendliness is the root of all toolchain jankiness, perhaps
    • It moves complexity around without fundamentally reducing it

• A famous 2009 Google paper, The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Data: simple algorithms and more data beat complex algorithms and less data

  • One can also think about AI in terms of time rather than intelligence

    • Modern AI is better understood as “Artificial Time” that can be prosthetically attached to human minds
    • Highly capable computing systems are best understood as existing in superhistory rather than embodying superintelligence

• Augmenting humans with machine learning in the right way raises their effective experiential age.
  • Here is where the training/inference cost asymmetry kicks in:
    • You need vast pools of powerful computers to train the best, biggest models, but
    • you mostly only need much cheaper personal-scale computers to do inference with those models.
  • So the hundreds (or thousands) of years worth of experience:
    • are logged in expensive infrastructure living in superhistorical time, but
    • are usable at human scale in historical time

• Lived human experience is not worth as much as you might think
  • Every scientific or technological revolution tears down yet another anthropocentric conceit
    • This one (ML) is tearing down the conceit that our lives are significant in informational terms
    • The humbling thing about the rise of machine learning is
      • not that it shows us how stupid we are in “intelligence” terms, but
      • how empty our lives are, in terms of their information content
  • Ideas like “building a second brain” leverage this basic new potentiality in the human condition:
    • our newfound ability to age faster than we can live, by
    • using machines to do much of the superhistorical living for us

• In information theory, the kind of disorder called entropy is the lack of structure or compressibility in data. Consider:

    • ...a rectangular field of pixels which can be either black or white.

      • A field of pure black or pure white has maximum order, in the sense of Shannon entropy:

      • you hardly need any bits to explain how to recreate the image.

      • This is not a mess.

    • ...a rectangle of pixels specified by a random process, with black and white equally likely.

      • There is no way to compress this data: each pixel must be specified separately.

      • It has maximum entropy.

      • But it, too, is not a mess.

    • ...a rectangle of black and white pixels formed from a series of overlapping corporate logos, themselves superimposed over a background text.

      • It takes fewer bits to specify than the randomly pixelated rectangle.

      • There are repeated letter forms, geometric forms… There is much more order and compressibility here.

      • And it’s a mess.

  • Why are tableaux that are apparently more "orderly" (in the sense of compressibility in the data required to specify them) also more messy?

    • For mess to appear, there must be (in the component parts of the mess) an implication of that highly-regular order which is associated with human intention.

    • "Mess" is only perceptible because it produces in our minds an imaginary order that is missing.
cite: Tendrils of Mess in our Brains

notes.content:
• A great deal of our reality is made from imaginary orders we carry around in our heads.
    • We use these imaginary orders to rebuild, navigate, and judge our world.
    • A mess is a visceral clue to the existence of these invisible orders.
cite: Tendrils of Mess in our Brains

notes.content: • Archibald Hill: “All writing represents speech”; John DeFrancis: “Writing is visible speech.”

• Vowel signs come from the Greeks repurposing Phoenician letters (which were abjadic)
    • They extracted those that didn’t match to sounds in their language, and were thus ‘extra’
    • Example: aleph in Hebrew is the glottal-stop represented by the Phoenician ~k char that was rotated to become the Greek alpha

• “Writing develops for agrarian-administrative purposes” is a now-debunked myth:

    • Mesopotamia/Mycenaean: here, earliest writing does describe borrowing, grain hauls, palace bureaucracy – but…

    • Cypriot/Cretan syllabaries: heroes’ historical exploits

    • Shang oracle bones: religious diviniation

    • Egypt, Mesoamerica: names and titles of royalty

  • It's an example of the teleological fallacy:

    • assuming a phenomenon originally came into being in order to serve [whatever is its current purpose]

    • e.g. “whale was always a sea creature” – but paleontology disproves

  • Counter-proposal: what’s one aspect of language that

    • cannot be easily conveyed by [mathematical, symbolic, magical, pictorial, etc] notation, but instead

    • needs to be recorded phonetically, as the series of their constituent sounds?

    • Answer: proper nouns - i.e. specific locations, specific people

      • This seems borne out by many cases of writing-system borrowing: - the first people from the borrowing culture to use a preexisting writing system - tend to do so to label items/assert ownership

• Acrophony: the naming of an alphabetic letter in such a way that its name begins with the letter itself.
  • Rune names and rune-values were so tightly coupled that runes were interchangeably used as logograms, e.g. 
    • the rune representing the sound “o” was named othila;
    • “othila” also literally meant “hereditary treasure”;
    • writers would often write “hereditary treasure” with a single letter “o”

• Chinese characters can be divided into five groups:
    • logograms (e.g. man, woman, horse) are directly derive from oracle-bone pictographs
    • representational signs or ideograms (e.g. numbers, up, down) aren’t strict pictographs; they express an abstract idea through an iconic form
    • relational units are a combination of two preexisting signs (e.g. moon and sun characters, written together, mean brightness – because that’s what they have in common)
    • rebus signs are pictographs that represent the image’s sound, not the image itself (e.g. lai as wheat => used as lai meaning to come/arrive)
    • phonetic-semantic signs combine a symbol of meaning with a symbol of sound (these are >90% Chinese characters)

• McLuhan: “The contents of any medium is always another medium”
    • A book conveys its contents: but also conveys writing, which itself is a medium that conveys the medium of speech
    • Books also convey paper, and all the relationships that go into raw-material procurement, refining, printing, distribution, etc

• Memory is a proxy for learning, which is a proxy for meaningful enablement. What questions can we ask about that relationship, e.g.

  • In what circumstances (and to what extent) does reliable-memory transfer to open-ended task-performance in the subject, e.g.

    • Can you explain the topic to someone else?

    • Can you spot unmentioned connections?

    • Can you solve problems you haven’t seen before?

  • What characteristics of prompts seem to promote this type of transfer learning? Through what mechanisms?

• A virtuous cycle:
    • powerful subject-matter ideas enable new systems, and
    • observations of those systems enable new insights into the subject matter.
  • The cycle might involve something like these steps:
    • Identifying powerful insights about some subject domain (or about cognition in general) which might be fruitfully systematized;
    • Building systems which express those insights in their primitives;
    • Observing serious use of those systems in authentic contexts (and of your theoretical insights, as refracted through them);
    • Distilling generalizable insights from those observations, which then
      • produce new understanding about the subject, and
      • allow new, better systems to be built
    • Disseminating that insight so that others can build on it
  • Most people interested in tools for thought are not reliably performing all these steps, which has left the field without a functioning ratchet.

• Ben Shneiderman’s schematic for research project design: the “two parents, three children” pattern

  • That is: (Basic Theories + Applied Problems) => Research Project => [Refined Theories, Practical Solutions, Guidance to Future Researchers]

• Two litmus tests for (e.g. SRS) assessments…

  • False positives: How might you produce the correct answer without really knowing the information you intend to know?

    • Discourage pattern matching (a long question with unusual words or cues)

    • Avoid binary prompts (questions which ask for a yes/no or this/that answer)

  • False negatives: How might you know the information the prompt intends to capture but fail to produce the correct answer?

    • Include enough context that reasonable alternative answers are clearly wrong

• As a medium, books have no direct means of communicating with readers over time
    • The physical text is stuck on the page
    • It’s read linearly and continuously in a few sittings
  • To be transformed by a book, readers must do more than absorb information
    • They must
      • ruminate on the book’s ideas and mental models, then
      • relate those ideas to experiences in their lives over weeks and months
    • Unfortunately, readers must drive that process for themselves

• If behavior is a function of a person in their environment (that is, B=f(P,E)), then it’s very difficult to modify P, but at least possible to modify E.
    • The average human has 11 million sensory receptors in their body: 10 million of them are dedicated to sight.
    • Because of this, visual cues in our environment are the most effective at influencing our behavior.

• Leverage the “Desire to Belong”
  • We imitate three groups of people:
    • The close (friends and family),
    • The powerful (people with status and prestige), and
    • The many (people in our society)
  • Surround yourself with people who already have the habits that you’re trying to develop.

• “Make it Unattractive”: to break a bad habit, eliminate the craving for that habit.
  • Either:
    • Expose how the bad habit inadequately addresses the underlying motive that caused its formation, or
    • Replace the bad habit with a good habit that more effectively addresses the underlying motive.

• Quantity Over Quality
    • If you want to master a habit, the key is to start with repetition, not perfection.
    • (example of the photography class w/ two groups, “more photos for higher grade” and “best single photo for higher grade”; best photos all came from former group)

• Motion vs Action
    • Reading a book on programming is motion. Actually programming is action.
    • We’re attracted to motion because it gives us the illusion of progress without the risk of failure.
    • Action is more difficult than motion, but it’s also more rewarding.

• To study consciousness, we first need to recognize it

    • Dehaene’s approach to this is simple and bold: a perception or a thought is conscious if you can report on it

    • The beauty of Dehaene’s approach is that he only extracts a single bit of information (yes or no)

  • Dehaene’s book is only about this definition of consciousness

  • For Dehaene, (the related concept of) attention is the gating mechanism that decides which information is allowed to enter consciousness

    • But this process itself is unconscious:

    • we are not aware of all the options that were considered and discarded, only of the winner

• To make perception unconscious in ordinary people…
  • These setups are useful, but they are not 100% reliable, more like 80% at best:
    • You don’t always perceive images consciously if they are presented
      • with a low contrast, or
      • for a short time
    • Binocular rivalry occurs if your two eyes are presented with different images
      • In this case, most of the time you don’t see a weird overlay of the two images, but
      • instead your conscious perception flips between seeing either one or the other
      • NB binocular rivalry is different in autistic people!
    • Attentional blinking describes the effect that
      • after a conscious perception,
      • you are consciously blind for anything that you see in the next 200-300ms
    • With Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) we can stimulate specific brain regions
      • By stimulating sensory areas, we can induce hallucinations, and
      • we can either make them conscious or unconscious by regulating the strength of TMS
      • By interfering with the right region at the right time, we can also prevent real perceptions from entering consciousness
  • One setup which works always, for everyone, is masking
    • The process:
      • you see some shapes (the “mask”),
      • then very briefly an image, and
      • then the shapes again
    • If the image is shown for 30ms, then people do not consciously see it, while for 60ms they do
    • This works with almost 100% accuracy, and has become the main workhorse for consciousness studies

• What can the brain do with unconscious information? A lot.

  • Your unconscious brain does not just process the letters of a word; it also deciphers the meaning.

    • For example, a masked “four” primes you not just for recognizing “four”, but also for “4”, “FOUR”, a spoken “four”, and even for “three”.
    • In fact, it primes you better for “three” than for “two”: the priming is stronger the closer the numbers are.

  • Unconscious perceptions can induce negative emotions

  • You can unconsciously distinguish faces and abstract categories like “object” and “animal”

  • You can unconsciously estimate averages.

  • Unconscious perceptions can control your attention: an unconscious “stop signal” will activate your executive control center in the brain.

  • You can also unconsciously detect errors

  • You can even learn new things unconsciously.

    • If you get a reward after each unconscious presentation, and
    • you get more reward after image A than after image B, then
    • you learn that A is worth more – even if you never consciously see any images at all!

• Unconscious perceptions are almost completely gone after a second
  • This means that tasks which require working memory can not be performed unconsciously.
  • Unconscious traces are too weak to be used as an input for a second step.
  • The exact point of complexity that can be performed unconsciously seems to be very low.
  • After seeing a number n unconsciously,
    • test persons are well above chance for the tasks of:
      • naming n,
      • naming n+2, or
      • deciding whether n<5
    • But deciding whether (n+2)<5 is already at chance level.

• Consciousness has a coordination effect.
  • Imagine you see some line moving in a diagonal direction over the screen.
    • Your neurons in the low-level visual areas cannot “see” the whole picture: they have only a limited perceptive field.
    • As such, it’s impossible to decide from their local information whether the line moves upwards, or to the right, or diagonally.
    • If the image remains unconscious, then these mismatches are never resolved.
    • However, if the image enters consciousness, then after 120-140 ms all neurons in the lower layers suddenly start to encode “it’s moving diagonally”
  • Dehaene’s description of this proces:
    • The unconscious (or pre-conscious) neural activity encodes a probability distribution over the possible states of the world.
      • If we see the word “bank”, then the meaning “credit institute” and “side of river” are both represented by some neurons, so
      • they both occur in this probability distribution.
    • When the word reaches consciousness, then
      • the brain samples from this distribution,
      • it decides one of the possible options, and
      • all neurons are overwritten with this meaning.

• Consciousness enables us to gauge our confidence.
  • That is, test subjects can say “I am certain” or “this was just a guess”.
  • And we are good at this: but only if the task was based on conscious perception.
  • If it is based on unconscious perception, then
    • we may still be good at the task itself, but our self-assessment is inaccurate.
    • often we underestimate our performance.

• Two different types of long-term memory, procedural and episodic
  • Procedural memory allows us to walk, ride a bike, or play the piano.
    • For this review, pooled together with semantic memory
      • the knowledge that birds can fly, or
      • things that you have learned by heart, like a song or the multiplication table.
    • We can acquire and access procedural memory unconsciously.
    • Acquiring procedural memory often requires a lot of practice and repetition.
      • This type of learning is usually slow and decentral in the brain:
      • Only the regions which are directly relevant to the task are involved in this type of learning.

• Two different types of long-term memory, procedural and episodic
  • Episodic memory refers to specific moments of your life,
    • e.g. remembering what you had for breakfast or what your conversation partner said five minutes ago.
    • This type of memory is one-shot: it’s instantaneously formed and does not require any repetition.
    • Aspects of episodic memory can be transferred into procedural/semantic memory
      • Sometimes after a few repetitions; sometimes just once
      • This particular interaction between the two types of memory is quite complicated, however

• Two different types of long-term memory, procedural and episodic
  • Episodic memory without consciousness is plainly impossible
  • However, consciousness also helps for procedural memory
    • Episodic memory can be transferred into procedural memory during sleep, and this is stronger than the effect of the direct experience alone.
    • Moreover, you only connect unconsciously-perceived events with each other if they are simultaneous (after all, unconscious neural activity fades away very, very quickly)

• One theory: the coherent activity of consciousness is exactly the form of neural patterns that can be stored in episodic memory.
  • That is, a conscious perception creates a(n episodic) memory-item that can be stored and retrieved later
  • A crucial property of memory is pattern completion: that you can retrieve the whole memory pattern from activation of a small part
    • So the word “croissant” may trigger the image of a croissant, the smell of it, the taste, the texture, and so on.
    • But the same works vice versa: the smell of a croissant also triggers the rest.
    • That is, there is no core of the concept “croissant” that needs to be present in order to trigger the whole concept.
  • For procedural memory, this is not a big deal
    • Since this memory is formed slowly,
    • there is enough time to nicely embed it into existing structures.
  • But episodic memory is one-shot learning: it needs to be formed in a second
    • It’s really hard to embed a complex concept so deep into an existing network that you still have pattern completion.
    • Every change in the brain needs to be cautious, because you have a lot of systems that should still be working after the change.
    • If each neuron represented its own interpretation of reality, then it would be pretty hopeless to encode all this into a retrievable pattern in just one second.
    • But it gets a lot easier if the activity of all neurons throughout your whole brain are highly consistent with each other… and that is precisely what consciousness seems to achieve

• For an unconscious perception, the main brain activity is in perceptual regions
    • The signal can travel further into the brain, but
    • only reaches a few regions, and
    • gets weaker and weaker.
  • A conscious perception does not get weaker; it gets stronger as it travels.
    • After 400ms, the conscious avalanche has activated large parts of the brain, which Dehaene calls global ignition.
    • All the brain parts synchronize, and information flows from all parts into each other.
    • “flow of information” is a well-defined quantity, measured by so-called Granger causality.
      • Granger causality is a useful concept with
      • a terrible name, since it is about a complex form of correlation, and not about causality.

• Consciousness has a severe disadvantage: it is really slow.
    • A conscious perception takes about half a second, 500ms.
    • This is ages compared to neural transmission speed of 70-100ms.
    • As such, a lot of our everyday life runs on autopilot.
  • Consciousness is also exclusive.
    • While a conscious perception is processed (which may consist of several components, like an image and a compatible sound), the activity blocks off other perceptions
    • They are either missed completely, or can only be processed after the 500ms are over.
  • So our consciousness:
    • runs at most at 2 perceptions per second, and
    • (other than unconscious operations) can not be parallelized.

• So consciousness has upsides and downsides.
  • It is really slow, it is exclusive, and it simplifies the world into a highly compressed sample.
    • This can be useful in its own right, for example to make a decision.
    • A lot of information is lost in this process, but apparently the resulting pattern is so simple that it can be processed further.
  • Since all parts of the brain participate in a conscious event, it is also universally available in the brain.
  • A conscious thought does not need to be triggered from the outside.
    • It can also be the next step of a mental algorithm, like the next thought in a train of thoughts, and
    • It can come (fully or partially) from episodic memory or mental associations.
      • Due to their simplicity, these memory items can often be expressed in language, and thus
      • they can be transmitted to others.

• There are at least two different ways of phrasing what happens when sensory input like the color “red” leads to some neural activity
    • Classically, we would say that “I” or “the brain” experiences the color red. The hard problem of consciousness assumes that this experience is something that goes beyond neural activity.
    • In the book Consciousness Explained, Daniel Dennett argues that a more appropriate description is the multiple drafts model (also called Cartesian theater)
      • the brain is a collection of many different regions
      • Each region acts like a little agent with its own perception.
      • The experience is then just the collection of these local experiences.
  • Critics like John Searle find that the multiple drafts model can’t explain why experiences are first-person, i.e., where the “I” comes from.
    • I think this is precisely the point that Dehaenes’s book helps us to understand.
    • My claim is: Given what we know about consciousness, if we assume the multiple drafts model, then we should naturally expect the subjective perception of a first-person observer.
  • Remember that our episodic memory might be exclusively formed from conscious moments, and also implicit learning gets a strong boost from consciousness.
    • So when “we” (our brain) learn a “mind schema”, then this is based on the conscious moments, not on the activities in between.
    • On this basis, it makes sense to merge all our neural activity into a single unit, which we call “I” or “my mind”.
    • We similarly form the unitary concept of “my body” – but even stronger, since we never “observe” different parts of our mind to be incoherent or even independent.

• Using our memories changes our memories
    • The brain does not store facts, ideas, and experiences like a computer does (as a file that is clicked open, always displaying the identical image.)
    • It embeds them in networks of perceptions, facts, and thoughts.
    • Slightly different combinations of these bubble up each time.

• Hand-written notes are superior to typed
    • At least partially because the former forces you to focus more on the semantics (vs pure syntax) of the message you’re hearing
    • This derives from the need to rephrase, in order to compensate for the slower pace of notetaking.

• Set a countdown timer as you sit down to read a chapter
    • It’s not important to actually hit this goal; rather,
    • It’s to help you focus on reading through to the end w/o distraction
• Highlighting can be dangerous: it often confuses the user as to their actual recall abilities (vs their recognition skill)

• SQ3R for Active Reading:
    1. Surveying
      • prime the brain
      • skim the overview/headings/conclusion
    2. Questioning
      • focus the avenues of exploration
      • write out some Q’s that come to mind before reading
    3. Reading
      • read in order to answer the questions generated by #2
    4. Reciting
      • later, retrieve from memory what you read
      • imagine you were explaining it to a friend
      • important to use your own words to rephrase the material
    5. Review
      • still later, repeat #4
      • this time, use a deeper, more dialogic method
      • you should need to return to the passage for citations and details

• Job to Be Done: what does the user want to achieve?
    • Functional aspects
      • e.g. cost, timing, duration, location
      • Start with these, to quickly narrow down and focus your options
    • Emotional aspects
      • e.g. personal (how the user feels) or social (how the user thinks society sees it)
      • Subjective requirements, so harder to reason about quantitatively
      • Ultimately, higher ROI for persuasion
    • Good phrasing to start from: ‘I need ${x} so that ${y}.’

• Be careful of the trap of referencing user data that you already have.
    • It’s easy to use, and should be used: because it’s already there.
    • Don’t take for granted, though, that it includes all the information you need (it almost certainly does not.)
    • Be sure to ask yourself: what data do we wish we had?

• When researching:
    • Prewrite first, to arm yourself with questions and potential lines of argument which will then help you focus your exploration;
    • Prevent ‘research recursion syndrom’ by asking, after every few hours, whether you have:
      • At least 2 sources for each main argument, and
      • At least one source for each non-crucial point (and, if both are true, then stopping the research process in order to begin writing.)

• One of my tricks for writing essays had always been to give talks.
    • The prospect of having to
      • stand up in front of a group of people and
      • tell them something that wouldn’t waste their time
    • was a great spur to the imagination.

• Robert Bjork’s ‘desirable difficulty principle’
    • Memories have two types of ‘strength’
      1. Storage strength: once a memory is encoded, it can really only get stronger
      2. Retrieval strength: this does fade with time
    • The greater the difficulty in recalling a memory (i.e. the weaker the current retrieval strength), the greater the learning impact will be from recalling it.

• Next time you need to ask a senior dev for help,
    • Note down and later analyze where you got blocked, then
    • Think through how you could have gotten around that blocker yourself

• When problem-solving:
    • Write down your failed solution attempts, as
    • Reviewing them will help you envision new paths, via variations on them

• When you notice yourself thinking, consider whether it’s:
    • rooted in selfishness/desires,
    • rooted in hatred/aversion, and/or
    • rooted in unrealistic beliefs about the world.

• Adaptive Learning: eliminates need to ‘teach to the middle’ in larger courses
    • Works better with factual, procedural knowledge than with higher-order/strategic knowledge
    • As such, more appropriate to entry-level courses

• ekgrata, or ‘one-pointedness’
    • The ultimate/eventual goal of mindfulness: learning to concentrate
    • First step is mere awareness of when one fails to concentrate
    • Possible be distracted by thoughts, or by sensations
      • For the former, simply observe ‘thinking’; the latter, ‘feeling.’
      • After, return attention to movement/cycle of the breath

• Try to become a ‘T-shaped person’:
    • To be a generalist, you have to regularly seek out new ideas.
    • To become an expert, you have to feel almost obsessively curious about a specific topic.

• To disarm a harmful thought:
    • Replacement (with a helpful corrolary thought)
      • For desire, thoughts of the object-of-desire’s impermanence;
      • For animosity, thoughts of compassion for the object-of-dislike;
      • For delusion, thoughts based in reality.
    • Reflecting on Results (contemplate the consequences of the harmful thought: even if it’s simply ‘being a person whose mind frequently harbors and conjures such thoughts’)
    • Reconstructing (examine the antecedents of the thought)
    • Redirecting (acknowledging that thoughts, like all else, pass away: then returning focus to e.g. the breath, or the elements of the body)
• Bhavana, or ‘cultivation,’ is closer to mindfulness practice than the term ‘meditation’ (it’s not about ruminating deeply)

• Adaptive Learning: several variants, along gradient of “time cost to develop” vs “later flexibility”:
    • ‘Closed’ system: premade adaptive logic and course content;
    • ‘Open’ system: requires user to configure course content and adaptive logic;
    • ‘Hybrid’ system: provides logic; user adds content (currently fastest-growing)

• Intelligent Tutoring Systems: differ from other computer-training systems in two ways
    • Can interpret complex student responses
      • Not merely from worked examples, but
      • Also from the details of requests (for assistance)
    • Can learn as they operate
      • First, build a profile for each student (from that student’s work and requests), then
      • Estimate each student’s level of mastery (in order to select future assignments)

• The mindfulness tradition holds that boredom is not caused by our circumstances
    • Rather, it’s the product of inattention
    • That is, it’s the result of withdrawing our full attention from what’s happening at the moment

• Robin Dunbar: the main force driving hominins to develop greater intelligence was increased social complexity.
    • Individual members of a society, like neurons in the brain, feature exponential growth in edges over linear growth in nodes
    • The number of social relationships, then, grows exponentially from even modest increases in overall group size
    • This exponential growth requires more intellectual horsepower
    • Evidence: cortex size co-varies with group size across several species

• Mindfulness:
    • A moment-by-moment awareness
    • The process of attentively observing your experience as it unfolds, without judgment or comparisons
    • The recognition of each thought as a momentary event that passes through the mind

• One early discovery in research on Intelligent Tutoring Systems: struggling students should explain what they do understand to the tutor
    • The tutor then can provide just enough hints for the student to work out the solution on their own
    • Better than the traditional model (i.e. the tutor reexplaining the process via a different analogy, medium, level of detail, etc.)

• Intelligent Tutoring Systems often currently interact with complex student behavior (‘more than just the answer’) by
    • breaking complex tasks down into sequences (or trees) of process-based steps, each of which
    • requires the student to provide some form of “work” (e.g. a diagram/equation/summary/etc.)

• Effective practice:

    • Starts with massed practice (for fast learning), then

    • proceeds to distributed practice (for retention)
• ‘Long-term potentiation’ is the process of neighboring neurons wiring together from firing together

• Reconsolidation
    • whenever a previously-consolidated memory is recalled into working memory,
    • it is vulnerable to alteration by any information already in working memory
• The human mind is likely a hybrid system: one that learns fuzzy associations and crisp rules in different subsystems.
• People form categories that give them an advantage in reasoning about the world, by allowing them to make predictions about things they have not directly experienced

• A problem with using neural-networks as a model for the human brain:
    • The e.g. Rumelhart & McClelland (1986) pattern-associator only produces past-tense forms
    • You cannot ‘turn the arrows around,’ getting the model to run backward and recognize past-tense forms
    • Obviously, people’s brains do both

• The ‘blocking principle’ of irregular verbs:

    • When you produce an irregular form, you have to:

      • not only dredge it out of memory, but also

      • repress the ‘add -ed’ rule (so you don’t say e.g. breaked or broked)

    • Words and rules are accessed in parallel

      • As we plan to utter a verb in the past tense, we simultaneously

        • look up the word in memory and

        • activate the rule

      • An inhibitory link runs from the memory-module to the rule-module

      • The memory-module can then gradually slow down the rule-module, as evidence for a match is found

      • It may eventually turn the rule-module off for that retrieval

• A problem with using neural-networks as a model for the human brain:
    • Multiple dimensions of influence may not be encoded.
    • For example, the Rumelhart & McClelland (1986) pattern-associator cannot tell the difference between two words that have the same sound.
    • The model has no knowledge of of lexical entries; it relies entirely on a word’s sound
    • That won’t work, though, for verbs like ring—rang/wring—wrung, break—broke/brake—braked, or meet—met/mete—meted

• We often have no choice but to use Wittgenstein’s family-resemblance categories
    • Many things we find around us could not be deduced by any body of laws, because they are shaped by myriad events of history no longer visible to us
    • Not all such categories start off in lockstep and then diversify, but probably all are governed by:
      • hidden laws that make them similar, and
      • historical contingencies that make them different

• Do your project/product for fun, then when it becomes overwhelming set up a company.
    • ‘Place small bets’
      • first on your own, in your class; then
      • Using gSites for a few friends; then
      • trial with 4.0 Schools
      • Each time, test a progressively more important hypothesis
    • Remember, a startup is inherently temporary
      • It’s a search for a model, not an institution.
      • Steve Blank: ‘a startup is just a discovery process for a business: once you have a sustainable, scalable model? Then it’s a business.’

• Paul Grice: the four maxims
    • Not advice: rather, a description of the conventions underlying communication
    • Maxim of quality: assume interlocutors will both
      • speak the truth, and
      • expect the truth
    • Maxim of quantity: assume interlocutors will
      • relay the entirety of information necessary for the current interaction, and
      • not relay more information than the interaction requires
    • Maxim of relation: assume interlocutors will provide only information that is relevant to the current interaction
    • Maxim of manner: assume interlocutors attempt to
      • avoid obscurity,
      • avoid ambiguity,
      • communicate briefly, and
      • communicate in an orderly manner

• Customs continue to constrain you long after the restrictions that caused them have disappeared.
    • Customary VC practice had once, like the customs about publishing essays, been based on real constraints.
      • Startups had once been much more expensive to start, and proportionally rare.
      • Now they could be cheap and common, but
        • the VCs’ customs still reflected the old world, just as
        • customs about writing essays still reflected the constraints of the print era.
    • Which in turn implies that people who are independent-minded (i.e. less influenced by custom) will have an advantage in fields affected by rapid change (where customs are more likely to be obsolete).
      • Here’s an interesting point, though: you can’t always predict which fields will be affected by rapid change.
      • Obviously software and venture capital will be, but who would have predicted that essay writing would be?

• When thinking about what to focus on, there are two distinct questions to ask:
    • What secrets is nature not telling you?
    • What secrets are people not telling you? (Secrets about people are relatively underappreciated.)
• The first step thinking clearly is to question what we think we know about the past
• If you can identify a delusional popular belief, you can find what lies behind it: the contrarian truth.

• The best place to look for secrets is where no one else is looking: what fields
    • matter, but
    • haven’t been standardized and institutionalized?

• War is costly business: rivalry causes us to
    • overemphasize old opportunities and
    • slavishly copy what has worked in the past
• Successful people find value in unexpected places, by thinking about topics from first principles instead of formulas.

• Much of the public sphere of life comes from tensions between:
    • family resemblance categories built from experience
      • these resonate with common sense, but
      • leave us groping when faced with something that is neither fish nor fowl
    • classical categories defined by science, law, or custom
      • these offer neat divisions, but
      • are bound to seem legalistic, pedantic, or abstruse

• It’s not that unprestigious types of work are good, per se.

  • But when you find yourself drawn to some kind of work despite its current lack of prestige, it’s a sign that:

    • There’s something real to be discovered there, and

    • You have the right kind of motives.

      • Impure motives are a big danger for the ambitious.

      • If anything is going to lead you astray, it will be the desire to impress people.

  • So: while working on things that aren’t prestigious doesn’t guarantee you’re on the right track, it at least guarantees you’re not on the most common type of wrong one.

• Two unrelated, oft-confused ‘rates’:
    • Rate of learning: the speed with which information is encoded (from working memory to long-term memory)
    • Rate of retrieval: an independent, learned skill that can be taught and improved

• Chunking
    • Occurs when working memory perceives a set of data as a single item
    • Allows us to increase the number of items that working memory can simultaneously handle

• Some of your assumptions are wrong. The problem is, you don’t know which ones.
    • The only way to be sure that your efforts are not in vain is to spend some time with users.
    • Study of >100 startup postmortems: #1 reason for failure, by a large margin: ‘no market need’
• Steve Krug: ‘The main thing you need to know about instructions is that no one is going to read them.’

• Most common design mistake:
    • Confusing the following:
      • a user’s goals (what they want to accomplish) with
      • a user’s tasks (how they accomplish it).
    • Tasks change as technology changes, but goals have the pleasant property of remaining very stable.

• People interact with computers and software much like they would with another human.
    • Think of your product as a person: what type do you want it to be? Polite? Stern? Forgiving? Strict? Funny? Deadpan? Serious? Loose?
    • Try to design software that acts like a considerate human being who remembers you.
• Instead of error messages, provide help and guidance: explain how the user’s input differs from what the program needs
• When you A/B test, you often find that most of your features either hurt your metrics or have no impact.

• All distributed systems are subject to the CAP theorem.

  • It is impossible for a distributed computer system to simultaneously provide all three of the following guarantees:

    • Consistency: all nodes see the same data at the same time;

    • Availability: every request receives a response about whether it succeeded or failed;

    • Partition tolerance: the system continues to operate despite arbitrary message loss, or failure of part of the system

  • In practice, all distributed systems must choose P, so the real question is: maintain consistency or availability?

• Create an environment that maximizes:
    • autonomy (we want to decide: what we work on, when we work on it, how we work on it, and who we work with)
    • mastery (we want to get better at things), and
    • purpose (we want to build something bigger than ourselves, to leave our mark on the world)

• We work more effectively when we continually alter our study routines
    • Abandon ‘dedicated space’ in favor of varied locations, to multiply the number of perceptions connected to a given memory
    • The brain picks up patterns more efficiently when presented with a mixed bag of (related) tasks, as well

• Old Theory of Disuse: memories evaporate entirely from the brain over time if they’re not used.
  • New Theory of Disuse:
    • No complex memory comes back exactly the same way twice
    • The act of forgetting filters some relevant details (along with many irrelevant ones.)

• Due to the passive side of forgetting (the fading of retrieval strength over time), deeper learning is facilitated once a fact or memory is found again.
  • The harder we have to work to retrieve a memory, the greater the subsequent spike in retrieval strength (that is, in learning.)

• Don’t work straight from their notes when reviewing.
    • Instead, create an entirely new outline, thereby forcing you to reorganizing the material.
    • This in turn forces you to think about the material again, and in a different way.

• Spacing is primarily a retention technique.
    • Having more facts on board could very well help with comprehension, too
    • For now, though, data supports it solely as a memorization strategy

• The ‘fluency illusion’: the belief that,
    • because facts or formulas or arguments are easy to remember right now,
    • they’ll remain that way tomorrow or the next day.

• Arthur Gates’ research: whether there’s an ideal ratio between reading (memorizing) and reciting (rehearsal/practice)
    • He concluded the best results are obtained by introducing recitation after devoting about 30 percent of the time to reading
    • That is, spend the first third of your time memorizing the content, and the remaining two-thirds challenging yourself on it

• Henry Roediger III and Jeffrey Karpicke’s 2006 review of a century of experiments across all types of retention strategies
    • They showed that the testing effect had been a strong, consistent ‘contaminant’ all along
    • To measure any type of learning, after all, you have to administer a test

• Pretesting: you’d almost certainly fail a first-day test of a course’s content
    • That experience, however, would influence what you subsequently pay attention to and process during the semester
    • Unsuccessful retrieval attempts aren’t merely random failures; rather, they alter how we think about, and store, the information sought by the questions
• Kerr and Booth’s research: a varied practice schedule may facilitate the initial formation of motor schema (e.g. hitting tennis balls)

• Psychologists who study learning tend to fall into one of two camps: the motor/movement, or the verbal/academic

  • The Molaison studies support this: they indicate that the brain must have at least two biological systems for handling memory

    • One (for declarative memories) is dependent on the hippocampus

    • The other (for motor memories) is based in different brain organs (no hippocampus is required)

    • The two systems are likely distinct, too, in how they develop, strengthen, function, and fade

• Interleaving: the process of mixing related but distinct material during study
    • Essentially, preparing the brain for the unexpected
    • Goode and Magill: whenever researchers scrambled practice sessions (e.g. location or serving-side of tennis court) people improved more over time than if their practice was focused and uninterrupted
    • Kornell and Bjork’s painting study (displaying six each of a dozen painters’ works; students who saw the paintings interleaved better identified artists’ new paintings than students who’d seen all six of an artist’s works at once) indicates this happens not merely for motor memories, but declarative ones as well

• Sapir-Whorf hypothesis: languages differ in what they permit their speakers to convey.
  • Boas-Jakobson principle: languages differ in what they require their speakers to convey.

• The real effects of a mother tongue are the habits that develop through the frequent use of certain ways of expression:
    • the concepts we are trained to treat as distinct,
    • the information our mother tongue continuously forces us to specify,
    • the details it requires us to be attentive to, and
    • the repeated associations it imposes on us.
• The fundamental principle of product development: surprises only get more expensive if discovered later.

• Two deadly sins of assumption:
    • Assuming that you know what users want
    • Assuming that users know what they want
  • People are generally much better at describing past behavior than in predicting future behavior

• Three deadly sins of fuzziness:
    • Not having detailed requirements
    • Not having a detailed project plan
    • Not knowing who’s responsible for accomplishing what
• Seeing the world in a grain of sand is often the way of science: geneticists agreed to study the lowly fruit fly so that their findings might cumulate into a deep understanding.

• Why has no language used combinatorial grammar to abandon the onerous laundry list called vocabulary?
    • It would force users to perform a chain of computations in their heads every time they wanted to refer to even quotidian objects.
    • Words would be packed tight with information, lacking the safety of redundancy (thus the slightest slip of the tongue or pen would guarantee misunderstanding.)

• Proto-Indo-European appears to have used internal-vowel shifts (ablauts) for past tenses.
    • High-front vowels come first in
      • expressions such as pitter-patter and dribs and drabs
      • pairs such as this and that, here and there, and me and you
    • This is true not only in English, but in many families of languages:
      • The higher and farther-to-the-front vowels are found in the word that means ‘self’ or ‘near the self’
      • The lower and farther-to-the-back word means ‘other’ or ‘far from the self’
    • Perhaps as Indo-European was developing, speakers vaguely felt that:
      • lower and farther back vowels fit better with the concept of an event separated in time from the present, and
      • higher and farther front vowels fit better with an event in the here and now
    • This contrast, between a higher front vowel and a lower back vowel, survives in the majority of modern English irregular verbs (via e.g. the ing—ang—ung class.)

• A neural network tries to accomplish intelligence using:
    • Hume’s law of contiguity (if A appears with B, associate them) and
    • Hume’s law of resemblance (if C looks like A, let it share A’s associations.)

• An example neural network: Rumelhart & McClelland (1986), for irregular past-tenses
    • 460 input units connected to 460 output units = 211,600 microrules total
    • The network’s final knowledge of a particular e.g. [word, irregular family, rule, etc] cannot be demarcated
      • One cannot point to a circumscribed part of the network that implements a given rule
      • Its understanding of the various verbs and their past-tense forms is smeared across the 211,600 connection strengths
      • The model ‘merely’ associates the phonological features of one word with the phonological features of another word

• Wittgenstein: a category can be extended to embrace new cases ‘as in spinning a thread we twist fibre on fibre. And the strength of the thread does not reside in the fact that some one fibre runs through its whole length, but in the overlapping of many fibres.’
    • Members of such categories are not created equal; they often have a best member or ‘prototype’ which sums up the category in people’s minds (e.g. the sparrow for ‘bird’, or wrench for ‘tool’)
    • Such categories often have fuzzy borders (people aren’t quite sure whether garlic, parsley, or seaweed should count as vegetables)
    • Such categories’ members often display ‘crisscrossing features’ (many vegetables are green, but carrots aren’t; or crunchy when raw, but spinach isn’t.)
    • Such categories often have stereotyped features, that everyone associates with the category, even if they have nothing to do with the criteria for membership (e.g. thinking of ‘gray hair and chicken soup,’ not of ‘node in a genealogical tree’, for grandmothers)

• The belief that ‘pain shouldn’t happen to us’ is a common cause of suffering
    • This is literally delusional: it’s inconsistent with the nature of the world
    • When you experience pain (during e.g. meditation):
      • First, simply attempt to deliberately, mindfully eliminate it (looser clothes, different cushion)
      • Second, simply observe: draw your attention to the pain, and investigate it
      • Become a bystander; notice its qualities, and impermanence

• John Austin
    • Three ‘actions’ in a speech-event
      1. Locutionary acts (what was said)
      2. Illocutionary acts (what was meant)
      3. Perlocutionary acts (what happened as a result of what was said and what was meant)
    • When one attempts to communicate, they are hoping that:
      • their locutionary act will properly map to
      • the correct illocutionary act to
      • produce the desired perlocutionary act.

• Memory is a proxy for learning, which is a proxy for meaningful enablement. What about creativity?

  • In Seeing What Others Don’t, Gary Klein suggests that key patterns of insight generation include noticing connections and contradictions.

    • Those both seem dependent on what’s in one’s memory.

    • So: can memory systems make us more insightful?

  • If we designed a new “memory system” with the sole aim of downstream impact on creative work:

    • What would it look like?

    • Would it involve retrieval practice at all?

mokkos.content:
Idle thought: is there a correlation between

[1] the strength of episodic memory of reading a given book (e.g. because it took place on a beloved vacation, or during some personally-meaningful event) and

[2] the semantic memories generated by reading that book?

(This is not at all to suggest operationalizing such a -- hypothetical -- relationship by attempting to ensure that only the most important books are read during episodically-charged circumstances!

Indeed, a negative correlation is even imaginable: the neurons fire around the process of reading the book, rather than any of its content.)

The base note helps reinforce the degree to which "choice architectures" are, while novel in the sense that they are rarely remarked on and often invisible, ultimately yet another tool designed by (and for the use of) humans.

I wonder to what degree the tropes of the gun-legislation debate can be replicated productively here: "the only way to stop a bad guy with a choice architecture is a good guy with a choice architecture"?

And if, per the base note, "our relationship with our tools is going to be how we move forward" -- how does the relationship with usage-of-choice-architecture vary across different slices of society?

This could be one human-centered use-case for at least some AI: acting as an external submodule of the brain, a first-pass filter to select out what the conscious brain should even focus on (when engaging in tasks that require rapid sequential conscious-processing... on realtime data streams... what sort of tasks are you imagining? Drone piloting?)

The analysis of the cue note makes me feel a little better about the claims of the base note -- of course lived human experience isn't worth that much; in neurological terms it's incredibly expensive!

I wonder, though, if this definition of consciousness can be applied to the ongoing debates about what constitutes "true AI" -- the ability to generate episodic memories based on the coordinated actions of several submodules, thereby intertwining a variety of mental observations into a single grouped (and thus reportable, the key Dehaene criterion) item?

I wonder to what degree the Wayne Gretzky Game is only playable in a field that has something analogous to Moore's Law -- a confident prediction of reliable improvements over the coming years/decades.

I suppose the Wayne Gretzky Game is a hack of the cue-note's "virtuous circle" -- paying for those so-new-as-to-not-yet-exist systems (or even simply imagining that already exist, and proceeding entirely in the realm of thought experiment?) in order to generate those insights into subject matter.

The combination of these two notes feels like a hint that the idea of "No Starch University books' content; your presentation and exercises" as your next step could be productive: while learning the subject matter in those books, also thinking through (and hopefully even building) ways to better inculcate that content than a static text/flat-file.

MetaMokko: typically would make more sense to skip one of these two notes, as they both denote related factual statements.

Recording a mokko instead, here, in order to ensure you return to the idea of how best to balance "notes whose claims are grounded in reality and thus relevant" with "notes which are ultimately better suited for anki".

At first pass, not sure there's any programmatic or heuristic solution; you're recording this mokko with the goal of revisiting after some time to let the background threads run percolation.

This is a great collision: the cue note uses the word "memory" as the starting point for a host of valuable questions... while the base note disaggregates the meanings contained in that word into more precise, distinct definitions.

Very pleased: this is precisely the sort of thing I built the app in the hopes of producing.

(Apropos nothing in these cards; still thinking about NSU: are there in-browser methods of munging [chunks of] an uploaded PDF directly into HTML? Could be useful for an end-to-end processing pipeline, assuming the majority of the learning interactions take place using the DOM)

From the cue note: "key patterns of insight generation include noticing connections and contradictions...Those both seem dependent on what’s in one’s memory" surely is using the word "memory" as shorthand for "semantic memory", no ? An idea for no answer immediately arises in my mind: how would such "connections and contradictions" be structured or noticed, in procedural memory?

The Wayne Gretzky Game could be used to implement the base note prescription: that is, when an activity is too costly to practice frequently, first leveraging (or imagining) near-future tech that would remove that cost constraint, and then behaving as if it were inexpensive to engage in with the "quantity over quality" skill-acquisition strategy.

The first example that comes to mind is the same as the base note: it would have been significantly more expensive to practice one's photography pre-digital cameras (and then smartphones).

What are other skills that depend on "technologies whose costs are falling rapidly/absurdly" in order to practice? The first category that comes to mind is any skill that depends on until-now-industrially-large amounts of electricity, given the plummeting costs of solar/wind installation... but what might those be? Metallurgy? A variety of chemistry subfields depending on electrolysis or similar processes?

Oh man, this is a kind of cool way in which (it sounds like?) linguistic structures recapitulate biological structures: the tight coupling of the reference and referent to either speed up global ignition or strengthen Granger causality?

The base note was written before the recent explosion in LLM's, but the cue note causes me to think of it in the context of human-AI (well, DNN+) interactions.

The solution for avoiding false negatives seems like it would be similar across both interactions (human-assessment questions, and LLM prompts) -- but, interestingly, neither of the solutions for avoiding false positives AFAIK seem very effective in preventing LLM hallucinations.

How does the "second brain" movement fare in terms of basic theories?

Has there been substantive research done into the benefits of [hierarchy/graph-organizable, bidirectional-linkable] knowledge bases?

Equally important, what might the "applied problems" of the research project be: what metrics can be ascertained for e.g. organizing and connecting information? (This question has more than a little relevance for one of your ongoing software projects, too, no?)

To actually make use of both notes, I suppose I should proffer the aside I suspect the field of neuroscience is one long series of battles with the teleological fallacy across different modules and behaviors of the organ.

I'm most thinking, right now, of the cue note's final bullet point: do we have any insight into how the competing options are sifted, discarded, and eventually selected? If the attention-gating process is unconscious, does it nevertheless have a semi-predictable rubric to which stimuli can be tailored?

These two cards pair really well together, almost as an unanswered SAT-style analogy question, i.e.iPad:Mac::Books:<???>

Or, inverted, dumbed-down-iPad-gestures:reading-linearly-and-continuously::universe-of-Mac-actions:<???>

Really, the more I think about it the more I'm reminded of the screenshares that Andy Matushak has provided of his Orbit WIP...

Do different media convey "the desire to belong" differently, or to stronger/weaker degrees?

The first idea that comes to mind is the notion of [TV's limited, homogeneous selection] versus the internet's near-infinite variety...

...On reflection, though, the breadth-of-available-channels between the two media is perhaps less relevant to conveying "the desire to belong" than the option-for-interactivity: content-providers can both be messaged and respond to those messages, with all of the possibilities for ingroup dis/approval that follow.
Extending the "two kinds of tools" model... could one imagine individual neurons as physics-friendly tools and consciousness as the user-friendly tool?

Given the importance of visual sensory receptors, to what degree [do, could] different [real, hypothetical] writing systems influence behaviors?

Other notation systems (e.g. mathematical, musical, scientific) could be even more productive lines of inquiry, here.

s/"writing, per base note"/"book-which-drives-that-process-itself, per cue note"

How might that latter tool develop? For the sake of the thought experiment, apply the same assumption of teleological fallacy's presence. (That is, assume that such a tool would not develop directly for improved learning and scholarship -- outside the realm of textbook publishing.)

In which non-learning contexts might you want "a book, but one that drives the rumination-and-relation described in the cue note"?

(Literary fiction) book clubs, with their discussion prompts and reading guides?

Test-prep/certification self-study guides? (Remember your driver's license renewal text, with its ~"now go outside and practice this three times before returning to read the next chapter" exhortations.)

Coffee-table book publishers, with their emphasis on the material presence and openness-to-physical-interaction of the book?

What visual modifications to one's personal environment might be very expensive now, but less expensive in 15 years?

The first thing that comes to mind is large-scale (like, larger than 11" diagonal smfh) e-ink readers, internet connected and designed to display large-scale text (and/or, better, Goya and Dore prints...)

Thought experiment: how many of the types-of-Chinese-characters are used in the generation of UI icons for the e.g. iPad?

Logograms, definitely (and, in our current era, often anachronistically! Looking at you, floppy-disk).

Ideograms, as well (and for many of the same ideas, as well as genre-specific ones like "circle-with-a-vertical-line-through-the-top" to represent "power on/off").

I'm having a difficult time thinking of the any examples of the other three: does that indicate that they're relatively underused, for generating user-interfaces' communicative images? Or that they've been tried and discarded?

One channels Ecclesiastes and instinctively assumes the latter ("nothing new under the sun", and all that...), so perhaps the more interesting question is: in what scenarios would those three character-types be preferred tactics for UI icon generation?

The DeFrancis quote perhaps misses the important part, the aspect of writing utilized in the cue note: not only is it visible, but it's durable speech.

By analogy, then, are reaction gifs merely durable gestures?

"Memory is a proxy for learning, which is a proxy for meaningful enablement."

Not a proxy: but one assumes per the base note that (beneficial) choice architectures can enhance each of these, as well. In what ways?

Facilitating that reliable-subject-memory => open-ended-tasks transfer? (And how? By encouraging different Webb-DOK tasks on subject-content whose memory-retrieval is already judged to be stable/successful?)

Facilitating the creation of prompts with those desired characteristics? (This feels reminiscent of some of the discussion around LLM-supported Anki-note creation.)

What research-or-practice opportunities would be opened up by spending "roughly two to three times your salary" (call it $250k) annually on technology?

More exploration of hardware-embodied tools for thought, definitely.

Possibly a more-deliberate exploration of machine learning for assistant purposes, given associated availability of impressive compute?

Perhaps most certain: far more plentiful (thus better) data collection (via grants, or even direct funding) -- with the goal of getting more empirical, confident indications of the utility/outcomes for different tools and even features.

Oof, I hate how these two notes align "the messages going around" and "environment E" so well.

Following that, I wonder if it's useful to recontextualize the base note in the context of the cue note's emphasis on visual primacy. Is this why the populace proved more resilient to talk radio than cable news? Is this why every breakroom is adorned with Comic-Sans-and-Clip-art 8x11's? Is this why we, as an industry, still fuck around with hero images?

Under the "Acceleration of Addictiveness" theory that "life is ever-more-frequently defined by what we say no to", perhaps there's benefit (or at least insight) to be gained from attempting something like a "text-only week" challenge, in which at the very least your browser is set to Firefox reader-mode by default. (The ideal version of this would be all input routed either through an eink reader... or vim. But that seems a little impractical.)
