The cue note's "can't contribute to forum conversation without preemptively stating the intent of your contribution" is fascinating to me in the light of the base note's focus on isolating/analyzing false-positives/negatives.

Specifically: requiring such "I'm only writing this because I want ___" metadata now allows the vectors-of-analysis of "outcome Y was achieved, but without typically-predictive-of-outcome-Y action X" and "outcome Y was not achieved, despite the presence of typically-predictive-of-outcome-Y action X", to a much more tightly-integrated signal than e.g. "total upvotes" or "green-checkmark'ed by question-asker."

(NB this leaves aside all ancillary potential benefits such as [1] discouraging reflexive, low-effort contributions or [2] acting as a prompt/dialogic-focus during the composition process.)

Perhaps one explanation for the reality of the cue note's "quantity-of-practice > quality-of-practice":

Assuming a time-series Cartesian plane where the dependent variable is "outcome of the task-under-practice": on a long-enough timespan, the line appears ~linear; on a shorter time span, it's quite (per the definition adduced in the base note) messy.

(NB this model assumes the base criteria for "deliberate practice" have been met: that is, there is a floor of practice-quality below which this model no longer holds, but not a ceiling above which e.g. improvements appear linear relative to some other metric of practice.)

A future task for you: collate two manifests of current tools-for-thought, from the chalkboard to ChatGPT.

Which are user-friendly tools? Which are physics-friendly? Are there cases where the distinction breaks down, or where the tool is better defined in relative (not binary-belonging) terms, on a gradient using the two as poles?

Then, the follow-up question: are there any commonalities between how the tools in each column fit into the Shneiderman model of research-project design?

Oof, IMVASIE ("in-my-very-anecdotal-statistically-insignificant-experience") it certainly feels like "increased concern for human comfort and convenience" can become a "motion-vs-action" moral hazard.

..."improved domain understanding", after all, typically requiring more hard-and-sometimes-feels-like-a-yak-shave work, with no guarantee of outcomes that will please your [clients, users, stakeholders, boss] any more so than e.g. "the on-hover button-gradient change now has keyframes!"

Question, then: how to incentivize the latter as the primary incitement of tool changes?

The base note is an excellent example of cue note: moreover, it's an example of the cue note that doesn't depend on Moore's Law (something you'd been looking for an example of for several days.)

So: first transistors, then storage, and now (hopefully) electricity all were/are on this happy curve of predictable, significant price-decrease.

Do ChatGPT-esque LLM's result in a similar curve for "~human interlocutor" -- or, as Strange Loop Canon put it, "analyst"?

If so, how would you use that (assuming near-free prices today)?

The first thing that comes to mind is signing up for the ChatGPT API for usage when building-while-using No Starch University, under the expectation that at some point a free, open-source, self-hosted version of the model weights will become available.

A potentially-useful model against which to check your behavior at any given point during the day:

Assume a "motion-vs-action" cline: ceteris paribus, speech will be closer to the motion end than writing, which will itself be closer to the motion end than doing.

By this logic -- coupled with the "writing doesn't record thinking; writing generates thinking" adage -- the act of writing occupies an undervalued middle-ground. Possibly even a transitional act between the (base note's definitions of) "Motion" and "Action"?

It thus seems like a whole swath of people could benefit from doing more writing more often, with a focus on using the act of writing as a tool for self-improvement in their given discipline (rather than a tool for generating strings of words to share with others.)

"Motion" is quite seductive (conservation of energy, and all that); the Shneiderman model is useful in that it makes visible (via the fat-arrows) the two locations in which the human-instinctive preference for motion prevents progress in the field.

Follow-up question, then: what can be done to decrease the friction of "shifting to action", at each of those two stages? That is, how to make it easier (and more enticing) to construct-and-execute-and-then-analyze-and-promulgate-the-findings-of a research project?

I have low confidence in this theory; raising it to provoke further thinking on the topic.

Is that "theory to practice to new theory to new practice" virtuous cycle described in the cue note an imaginary order, as described in the base note?

If so, is the scarcity of "functioning ratchets" feasibly interpretable as (what the base note terms) a mess?

And, if so, what does that imply about the structure of the base note's "virtuous circle"? Its completeness? Its necessity for tool-development and field-progress?

(To reiterate my confidence-level: possibly nothing, even taking all reasoning above as true. But I'd like to think on it further.)

A "reexamination of the past" applied to the base note first surfaces the following question: across history, what characteristics can be extracted from the the various "alternatives to books as a medium of instruction"?

(NB specifically for pedagogy, not speech-recording; i.e. as much as you want to learn more about the structure and practice of Incan counting-knots, they would be outside the scope of this historical review. So too would something like aristocratic 1-1 tutoring, as it's not a physical medium.)

In many cases, the answer is likely to be "nothing of value; these alternatives came to existence due to the absence/inaccessibility of books and across all metrics are simply inferior" -- thinking specifically of stained glass.

Nevertheless, I suspect the historical record supports unexpected variety and innovation across the panoply of scrolls, wax/clay tablets, illustrated texts, murals, etc. It might be useful to reexamine those characteristics in the context of how digital technologies can reinterpret and extend them.

What topics (or subfields, even down to the course level) currently:

1) require high-order/strategic knowledge, but

2) in 10 years may have been changed by technology to the degree that they require merely procedural (or even factual) knowledge?

That is, for which components of a given curriculum might one be able to play the Wayne Gretzky Game in terms of applying adaptive-learning systems ~prematurely, under the assumption that those components will be far more tractable to such systems in a few years?

I wonder the degree to which the cue note is responsible for the base note: that we severely overestimate the information-complexity fullness of our lives... because (at least partially due to the fluency illusion) we severely underestimate how much information is in fact retained over even trivial durations.
These notes pair excellently: each of the questions in the base note is one to be asked about any posited Intelligent Tutoring System.

Do different "steps along the ratchet" privilege, prioritize, or even require different media? Schematize this.

That is: what media are conveyed by ${the primary media, respectively, of "subject-domain insights" and "system construction"}? And, a la "paper and all its relationships", what material realities are conveyed by those media, too?

Does the cue note offer an (somewhat depressingly-reductive) explanation for the base note?

That is, above a certain fairly low floor, "more data" > "better learning strategies" for most learning practices? ...where the M in ML can be "machine" or "meat"?

I wonder what to make of the fact that the base note's description of machine learning broadly exists (at this time, and only as far as I know) solely in the latter "verbal/academic" camp of the cue note.

Is it the work of the hippocampus that makes the learning performed by biological neural nets replicable by computational ones?

Or are both human-types-of-learning mimicable by the same ML algorithms due to the sheer computational superiority of the latter?

"SQ3R for Active Reading" is (as far as I understand?) primarily designed for engaging with nonfiction, explicitly-pedagogical texts with the goal of mastering and memorizing it their content.

(It appears the book that first promulgated the methodology is literally titled "Effective Study" -- cf Francis Robinson, 1970)

What happens if, as a thought experiment, we (counterfactually) apply the assumption of the teleological fallacy, taking as given that SQ3R evolved for a wholly different end before being repurposed by learners?

That is, could one benefit from applying the methodology to e.g. a fictional text, read for [enjoyment, a deeper-albeit-nondeclarative understanding of the craft of prose]?

A work of classic cinema?

A codebase?

Interpolating "mother tongue" into the base note's main sentence as "medium" causes the sublists in each note to echo each other: a native language conveys not merely itself but also:

  • (elements of) each language from which it evolved;

  • the societal and material realities of the humans who used each of those languages; and

  • the somewhat-arbitrary, historically-contingent ways in which those realities imbricated and expressed themselves in the [syntax, semantics, phonology, etc] of those languages -- and of itself.

Can one create a choice architecture, inside of a study/learning tool, to habituate the conscious, strategic act of chunking?

And how to do so without distracting the learner from the task at hand?

Hahaha so chunking is just a very constrained, biological version of information-compression?

Which other, preexisting study-strategies/techniques can be viewed through a similar computational lens? Which (that don't exist yet) can be imagined?

Be pretty cool, as a research experiment, to build an adaptive-learning app for Chinese characters that responds to which types of characters you're having the most/least trouble retaining (perhaps by altering presentation of the constituent e.g. strokes/radicals, by increasing/decreasing the historical context provided for a given character, etc)

To better hone your own understanding of what you'd like to accomplish with your nascent "NSU" project, analyze it according to Shneiderman’s schematic:

  • What basic theories will you draw on?

  • What applied problems do you aim to solve?

  • How will the project to generate data to be analyzed: that is, what elements will make it a research project?

  • How might its conclusions refine preexisting theories? (And how does that answer modify your response to the question immediately preceding?)

  • What practical solutions might the conclusions offer?

It feels like you could create a nifty tool to help you implement the CN method ("when reviewing, create an entirely new outline rather than directly reviewing your prior notes") by playing the Wayne Gretzky Game with LLM's.

Dude, just buy a beefy-tower and pull down LLAMA already lol
Cue note contextualizes the base note: if you're drawn to action-over-motion in a given field, it's a pretty good indicator that "you have the right kind of motives"

Kind of nifty to reflect on an Intelligent Tutoring System that, among all of its other capabilities, deliberately tunes and selects its visual cues (its actual arrangement of UI) in response to the learner's current-day performance, current level of mastery, reported/perceived mood, other creepy stuff, etc

Has there been any research into whether

  • the practice-pattern stated in the cue note

  • exhibits any correlation to

  • any of the false-positive/negative-generating-practices listed in the base note?

That is, does the proven-to-be-beneficial-strategy nevertheless display any vulnerabilities to other, orthogonal, suboptimal strategies? Can it exacerbate them?

Wow, these two notes pair really well.

Does the distinction of tool-types diminish or disappear when, per the cue note, the human (user, subject) has been adapted sufficiently to exist in the environment (physics, direct objec)?

books have no direct means of communicating with readers over time

struggling students should explain what they do understand to the tutor

Idea for potential-feature of nascent SQ3RREL app: at the end of the Read (R1) stage, include an e.g. checkbox to elicit something like "do I feel like I've fully answered this question?" for each of the items generated in the Question (Q) stage.

For each item where the answer is not affirmative, have the form ask "what aspects/elements of the question do I feel like I now have answers for?" (preferred widget as-yet indeterminate, e.g. input vs textarea vs other)

TBD: what (if any) follow-up question should be present for when the answer to the initial question is affirmative? "what new questions -- possibly external to this textbook -- do these answers raise?" ...perhaps "how might I apply these answers to my own work?"

How does the precept of the cue note change in the world of LLM's?

On one hand, there's not really such a thing as error messages in the sense of "expected a string; got an integer" -- as far as I understand, any natural language input is suitable.

On the other hand, the fundamental unexplainability of a stochastic system leads to a situation where the program itself can't really conceivable criterion for "needs".

Do hive insects escape this derived evolutionary demand for cognitive growth, as required by exponential growth in social-graph edges, via their homogeneity?

By, I guess, duck-typing (or setting an interface) per social role (as opposed to per individual), such that (even if there are thousands of fellow-bumblebee-individuals with whom you might interact on a daily basis) you can abstract all potential interactions with them into "drone, queen, whatever-the-third-role-is-if-present"? Heh, biological OOP.

What are other cases where a computing pattern can be applied, with some munging, to an emergent property of the natural world?

The (by coincidence, literally encountered this morning!) idea of "VR's primary utility: offering a way to train inside simulations for activities which are far too expensive practice frequently in realspace" intertwines these notes.

Given the experience of the DoD with HoloLens (as I understand it, unusably nausea-inducing for protracted sessions?), then: what activities fit that above criterion but also can be meaningfully practiced in e.g. chunks of 15 minutes or less?

(The flipside being, I suppose, that if a device is both [1] very expensive and [2] unpleasant to use for more than a few minutes at a time... hey, you can save money by purchasing one headset for every 3-4 learners and sequencing sessions such each user cycles between "needs VR headset for this task" and "no headset needed", rotating the device between them.)

Could an adaptive learning tool:

  1. elicit learner judgments about what subcomponents of the material-to-be-learned are most interesting to them, then

  2. weight those subcomponents such that they receive more frequency-of-training, or more advanced question types, than the learner's performance might otherwise dictate?

Does the cue note imply an unintentional side-effect to the practice of the base note?

If you chunk disparate data together multiple times, can it actually change how your brain retrieves and even conceives of those data?

A potentially-interesting project for a lazy Saturday afternoon: break down different Unicode families, and distribute them into the five groups of the base note.

Calculate e.g. which groups are most/least represented in which families, which groups are most/least represented overall, perhaps whether any e.g. predominance of a particular group correlates to rate of emoji-usage in that writing system, intra-language etc

There's a contrast between these two notes that you may wish to reflect on more generally.

The cue describes a strategy that's open to anyone at any time, but (because of its biologically-imbricated nature) is severely handicapped in how much it can achieve.

The base describes another strategy, also aimed at achieving more within the limits of human cognition: but, while it does have greater dependencies (on e.g. electricity, hardware, software), it's so much more powerful that it almost obviates the practice of the cue-note strategy.

What to take away from this?

Base note is a pretty perfect concrete example of the principle elucidated in the cue note.

Kind of terrifying, on reflection, to realize how much you can change other humans' environments, at scale, simply by altering the tools that you sell to them (which they then surround themselves with and use daily).

Applying that principle that "surprises get more expensive the later they're discovered" to product described in the base note:

Assuming you don't want to frontload a ton of extra work onto the learner (in order to build a more accurate student profile/mastery-estimate) -- how can an intelligent tutoring system function effectively early on, when [1] the data it has is still quite sparse, and [2] users are more like to churn if not experiencing tangible benefits?

That feels like a predictive-modeling problem: which, as we've learned from AI Assistants, can first be attempted via statistical machine learning... and then (once a robust enough dataset is generated and then classified) can be passed on to train a DNN for still-better, more-granular performance.

Mess, then, can function as a very useful tool if approached properly: the "imaginary order which is missing" that it points to can, if widely held across society, itself point to a "delusional popular belief"... providing you a location to begin prospecting for the underlying, contrarian truth.

Successful implementation of the base note can, I suspect, deeply facilitate the practice of the cue note.

Concretely: when a learner unsuccessfully attempts a multi-step exercise, the application should

  • not only offer the feedback to help them succeed,

  • but also store the process of the failed solution attempt, and present it(s summarized/processed version) to the user again if/when they unsuccessfully attempt of similar version of the exercise (as a first step, to attempt to elicit memories of how they solved the previous exercise, before offering explicit feedback similar to what they received on that previous exercise. )

The hypothesis: this exposure to prior, unsuccessful work will help trigger the adjacent memories of the eventual success on that previous exercise, thereby increasing the task's Bjorkian "desirable difficulty" level.
